RCW 41.05.006 and 2018 c 260 s 2 are each amended to 15 read as follows: 16 (1) The legislature recognizes that (a) the state is a major 17 purchaser of health care services, (b) the increasing costs of such 18 health care services are posing and will continue to pose a great 19 financial burden on the state, (c) it is the state's policy, 20 consistent with the best interests of the state, to provide 21Z-0092.3 SENATE BILL 5700 State of Washington 68th Legislature 2023 Regular Session By Senators Van De Wege, Cleveland, and Dhingra; by request of Health Care Authority Read first time 02/03/23. Referred to Committee on Health & Long Term Care. p. 1 SB 5700comprehensive health care as an employer, to ((employees and school )) 1 public employees, officials, their dependents, and to those who are 2 dependent on the state for necessary medical care, and (d) it is 3 imperative that the state begin to develop effective and efficient 4 health care delivery systems and strategies for procuring health care 5 services in order for the state to continue to purchase the most 6 comprehensive health care possible. 7 (2) It is therefore the purpose of this chapter to establish the 8 Washington state health care authority whose purpose shall be to (a) 9 develop health care benefit programs that provide access to at least 10 one comprehensive benefit plan funded to the fullest extent possible 11 by the employer, and a health savings account/high deductible health 12 plan option as defined in section 1201 of the medicare prescription 13 drug improvement and modernization act of 2003, as amended, for 14 eligible ((employees and school )) public employees, officials, and 15 their dependents, and (b) study all state purchased health care, 16 alternative health care delivery systems, and strategies for the 17 procurement of health care services and make recommendations aimed at 18 minimizing the financial burden which health care poses on the state, 19 ((employees and school )) public employees, and its charges, while at 20 the same time allowing the state to provide the most comprehensive 21 health care options possible. 22 Sec. 2. RCW 41.05.013 and 2006 c 307 s 8 are each amended to 15 read as follows: 16 (1) The authority shall coordinate state agency efforts to 17 develop and implement uniform policies across state purchased health 18 care programs that will ensure prudent, cost-effective health 19 services purchasing, maximize efficiencies in administration of state 20 purchased health care programs, improve the quality of care provided 21 through state purchased health care programs, and reduce 22 administrative burdens on health care providers participating in 23 state purchased health care programs. The policies adopted should be 24 based, to the extent possible, upon the best available scientific and 25 medical evidence and shall endeavor to address: 26 (a) Methods of formal assessment, such as a health technology 27 assessment under RCW 70.14.080 through 70.14.130 . Consideration of 28 the best available scientific evidence does not preclude 29 consideration of experimental or investigational treatment or 30 services under a clinical investigation approved by an institutional 31 review board; 32 (b) Monitoring of health outcomes, adverse events, quality, and 33 cost-effectiveness of health services; 34 (c) Development of a common definition of medical necessity; and 35 (d) Exploration of common strategies for disease management and 36 demand management programs, including asthma, diabetes, heart 37 disease, and similar common chronic diseases. Strategies to be 38 explored include individual asthma management plans. ((On January 1, 39 p. 7 SB 57002007, and January 1, 2009, the authority shall issue a status report 1 to the legislature summarizing any results it attains in exploring 2 and coordinating strategies for asthma, diabetes, heart disease, and 3 other chronic diseases. )) 4 (2) The ((administrator )) director may invite health care 5 provider organizations, carriers, other health care purchasers, and 6 consumers to participate in efforts undertaken under this section. 7 (3) For the purposes of this section "best available scientific 8 and medical evidence" means the best available clinical evidence 9 derived from systematic research. 10 Sec. 5.
